context: Chapter 1.3 — After a Pit win, Jade Winters of Apex Dynamics approaches the player.

lines.text: The crowd at the Pit is thinning out. Another win. Your name is getting louder in these hallways, and you can feel it — the way people step aside a half-second sooner, the way conversations pause when you walk past.
You're leaning against your car, counting your take, when you notice someone who doesn't belong.

She's standing at the edge of the crowd like a heron in a junkyard. Designer coat — camel, probably cashmere — over a black turtleneck. Her shoes alone cost more than most of the cars parked down here. Everything about her is clean in a place where nothing is clean.
She's been watching you. Not the race — you. And she's walking over now with the confidence of someone who has never been told no by anyone who mattered.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Impressive performance. The way you took that hairpin on the second lap — you left the racing line intentionally. Used the curb as a launch point. Most drivers down here wouldn't even see that option.
She extends a hand. Her grip is firm. A business handshake with intent behind it.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Jade Winters. Head of Talent Acquisition, Apex Dynamics.

choices.text: Apex Dynamics. The corporate racing outfit?
You're a long way from the boardroom.

lines.label: jade_explains_apex
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: You do your homework. Good. Yes — Apex Dynamics. Largest independent motorsport development company on the Pacific Rim. We scout, develop, and promote racing talent.

lines.label: jade_introduces_apex
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: You will. Apex Dynamics is the largest independent motorsport development company on the Pacific Rim. We find talent before anyone else does. That's what I do. I find people.

lines.label: jade_slumming
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Am I? Funny. Every great driver I've ever signed was racing in a place exactly like this. Basements. Parking garages. Mountain passes at two in the morning.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: The boardroom is where the money is. Down here is where the talent is. I've learned to speak both languages.

lines.label: jade_pitch
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I'll be direct with you. I've been watching the underground scene in Nova Pacifica for six months. Most of what I've seen is adrenaline and ego — fast hands, slow brains. People who drive angry.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: You're different. You adapt mid-race. You read the car ahead of you like a book. And tonight — that move in the hairpin — that wasn't instinct. That was engineering. You calculated it.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Apex is hosting a trial event next month. Invitation only. Professional-grade circuit, real equipment, real competition. Consider it an audition. No commitment, no contract. Just a chance to show what you can do with a real car on a real track.

lines.label: jade_details
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Apex Circuit. Forty minutes north of the city. I'll send you the details once you're registered.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Fair warning — the trial won't be like this. Down here, it's you and the car and the street. Up there, it's you and the car and a dozen engineers watching telemetry on screens you've never seen before. It's a different world.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Some people from the underground thrive in it. Some people choke. There's no shame either way. But I think you'll thrive.
She pulls a business card from her coat — real card stock, embossed, the Apex logo catching the fluorescent light.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: My direct line. Don't lose it. And don't give it to anyone.
She turns to leave, then pauses.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: One more thing. Whatever you're doing down here — the money, the reputation, the street cred — enjoy it. Because if you step into our world, all of that resets to zero. You'll be a rookie again. The question is whether you're hungry enough to start over.
She walks away through the crowd. People part for her without realizing they're doing it. That's the kind of gravity money buys.

lines.label: jade_rejection
lines.text: Something shifts in Jade's face. Not offense — recalibration. She was prepared for this answer.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Loyalty to the scene. I respect that. Most people would jump at the chance to leave this behind.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: But 'down here' has a ceiling. You'll hit it faster than you think. And when you do, the offer doesn't expire.
She places a business card on the hood of your car. Real card stock, embossed, the Apex logo sharp enough to cut.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: My direct line. For when 'good down here' stops being enough.
She walks away. Later, Diesel finds you outside. He saw the whole thing from across the room.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Suits. They come sniffing around every few years. Looking for the next thing to put in a commercial.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You said no?
You nod.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Good.
He doesn't explain why. He doesn't need to. That single word carries the weight of a hundred arguments he'll never make.

lines.label: jade_business_model
lines.text: Jade tilts her head. A smile — the first real one — crosses her face.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Good question. The right question, actually. Most people don't ask it.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Apex makes money two ways. First: we develop drivers for professional circuits. You win races, sponsors pay, everyone profits. Second: technology. The R&D that comes from competitive racing filters into consumer products. Every car on the road is better because someone pushed the limits on a track.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: What's in it for Apex is simple. We invest in raw talent. We provide training, equipment, support, and infrastructure. In return, we get a percentage of your competition earnings and endorsement deals. Standard industry arrangement.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: The real answer, though — the honest answer? I get a bonus when one of my recruits makes it to the pro circuit. So yes, I have a personal stake. I'm not pretending otherwise.

choices.text: I appreciate the honesty. Tell me more about the trial.
Thanks, but I'm not ready for that.

lines.label: jade_trial_info
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Apex Circuit, forty minutes north. Invitation only. You'll drive one of our prepared cars — not yours. We want to see what you do with real equipment and real competition.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: No commitment, no contract. Just data. We watch, we analyze, and if both sides like what they see, we have a longer conversation.
She hands you a business card. Real card stock, embossed, the Apex logo precise as a blueprint.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Think about it. My direct line is on the back.
She turns and walks through the crowd. People move for her like water around a prow. At the stairs, she pauses and looks back.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: For what it's worth — I've scouted a hundred drivers. The ones who ask what's in it for the other side are the ones who make it. You've got the right instincts. Don't waste them down here.
Then she's gone. Up the stairs, through the door, and back to whatever world exists above the one you live in. You pocket the card and feel its weight like a second heartbeat.

lines.label: jade_patience
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Ready is overrated. Most of the best drivers I've signed thought they weren't ready. But I understand.
She places a business card on the hood of your car.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: The offer doesn't expire. When you're ready — if you're ever ready — that's my direct line.
She walks away. Clean, efficient, no wasted movement. Like everything about her has been optimized for purpose.

lines.label: jade_end
lines.text: You stand in the parking lot, alone with your car and the echo of a world you've never seen. Corporate racing. Sponsors. Salaries. A real track with real equipment. It sounds like a dream. It sounds like a cage. It sounds like both.
